item.title: Ticket #1474 (Incorrect string cut for localized title and excerpt in wp_trackback.php.) created
item.dc:creator: zet
item.description:
Somewhere in wp_trackback.php (string 71,72,73): 

$title = (strlen($title) > 250) ? substr($title, 0, 250) . '...' : $title;
$excerpt = strip_tags($excerpt);
$excerpt = (strlen($excerpt) > 255) ? substr($excerpt, 0, 252) . '...' : $excerpt;

Function substr working properly only for english UTF-8 strings because codes of latin letters in ASCII same to UTF-8. But for cyrillic and other national symbols function substr works incorrectly. I recommend replace all substr inclusions for language-sensitive data with function wp_substr(): 

function wp_substr() {
        $function (function_exists('mb_substr'))?'mb_substr':'substr';
        return call_user_func_array($function, func_get_args());
}

item.title: Ticket #1473 (Admin Dashboard does not show comments awaiting moderation for first ...) created
item.dc:creator: gortsleigh
item.description:
If there are no approved comments in the database, the dashboard does not show comments awaiting moderation.

Proposed fix below (patch to wp-admin/index.php) The patch maintains all comment reporting within a separate <div> 

Index: wp-admin/index.php
===================================================================
--- wp-admin/index.php  (revision 2)
+++ wp-admin/index.php  (working copy)
@@ -47,16 +47,18 @@
 <?php endif; ?>
 <?php
-if ( $comments = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT comment_author, comment_author_url, comment_ID, comment_post_ID FROM $wpdb->comments WHERE comment_approved = '1' ORDER BY comment_date_gmt DESC LIMIT 5") ) :
+if ( $comments = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT comment_author, comment_author_url, comment_ID, comment_post_ID, comment_approved FROM $wpdb->comments ORDER BY comment_date_gmt DESC LIMIT 5") ) :
 ?>
 <div>
 <h3><?php _e('Comments'); ?> <a href="edit-comments.php" title="<?php _e('More comments...'); ?>">»</a></h3>
 <ul>
 <?php
 foreach ($comments as $comment) {
+   if ($comment->comment_approved) {
        echo '<li>' . sprintf(__('%1$s on %2$s'), get_comment_author_link(), '<a href="'. get_permalink($comment->comment_post_ID) . '#comment-' . $comment->comment_ID . '">' . get_the_title($comment->comment_post_ID) . '</a>');
        edit_comment_link(__("Edit"), ' <small>(', ')</small>');
        echo '</li>';
+   }
 }
 ?>
 </ul>

item.title: Ticket #1472 (Posts protected by password still go out in RSS feeds) created
item.dc:creator: john_roberts
item.description:
When a post is password protected, there is a loophole: the RSS feed.

If you send out full-text via the RSS feed, then the entire protected post goes out without password protection.

If you send out excerpts, then the first few lines go out unprotected. Less bad, but not good.

Workarounds:

  • Hack the wp-rss.php and wp-rss2.php files to hard-code the <description> field.
  • Remember every time to put in an innocuous excerpt just to avoid having the RSS feed take the first sentence or so into the <description>

The first workaround is OK, but requires extra work AND means that you can't switch back and forth between protected posts and public posts. Not a concern for me, but seems limiting.

The second workaround means that if you forget or are lazy, a protected post will go out (at least in excerpt form) via your RSS feed. You can change after the fact, but one a post goes out... it's out there! ;-)

Suggested solution: if a post has a password, then change the <description> field to reflect that, probably with a default message like "Visit the website to read this post after giving your password" or some such.

item.title: Ticket #1471 (404s show the index page) created
item.dc:creator: Leffe
item.description:
With the new (?) brief way of handling URIs, all unrecognized requests show the index of the blog. The problem seems unrelated to the permalink scheme used as it happens both with the default and my preferred style. Trolling around the source has left me with no clues as to what could cause this. Normal files already in the filesystem work well, as do directories. Any 404 on the server not handled by another .htaccess (which contains the generated directives and nothing suspicious) will also show the blog index.

Example:

/some/random/uri shows the index.
